Modus ponens is a rule of inference that states: if P then Q, and P is true, then Q must also be true. In this case, the statement "If the book was written by James, then the book is a mystery novel" can be represented as "If P (book was written by James) then Q (book is a mystery novel)". Modus tollens states: if P then Q, and not Q, then not P. But in this case, we are trying to infer that if Q (book is a mystery novel) then P (book was written by James), which is a different logical rule called affirming the consequent. Affirming the consequent is not a valid form of logical reasoning because it does not follow the rules of logic.
